Peter,

That is a surprising result. It seems like never changing the novel=
ty
scores would create attractors around old behaviors instead of new ones.=
 

For example, imagine an individual that reaches a new area in
behavioral=
 space. It is assigned a high novelty score. Several new
individuals arrive=
 in the same area, and get lower novelty scores (the
first one maintains it=
s high score). What we want is to explore the
individuals on the 'fringe' o=
f this new area, in hopes of finding
further areas of novetly. However, wit=
h constant novelty scores, the
bias will be to investigate the area in the =
proximity of the first
individual, even though the ones on the fringe may b=
e more promising.

If you consistently get better performance with constant=
 novelty
scores over a variety of maps perhaps it is worth looking into mor=
e.

Joel

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski=
@...>
wrote:
>
> Hi Joel,
> 
> Novelty search is one really inspiring idea.=
 
> It is interesting to note that when I added the dynamic adjustment of 
=
> the sparseness/novelty score, the performance was actually worse than 
> =
without adjusting the novelty score, i.e. an individual always stays 
> wit=
h the novelty score it was born with. 
> I hypothesize that this is because=
 it encourages such species that 
> produce more novel behaviors frequently=
. But I guess that the best 
> way is to recompute the novelty scores at re=
gular intervals.. 
> 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "joel278" <=
lehman.154@> wrote:
> >
> > Hi Peter,
> > 
> > Glad to hear that you are in=
terested in the method, and that you've
> > been able to implement it.
> > =

> > You are correct, the novelty of each individual is calculated with
> >=
 respect to the current population and the archive.
> > 
> > Yes, sparsenes=
s in the behavioral space around an individual is
> > equated with novelty,=
 which is used for the fitness of the 
> individual.
> > 
> > Ideally, nove=
lty would recomputed for each individual in the current
> > generation afte=
r each evaluation. In our implementation it is 
> allowed
> > to get stale =
for a few evaluations (in the same frequency that
> > individuals are respe=
ciated according to rtNEAT). In our 
> experiments,
> > allowing for a bit =
staleness did not effect the results.
> > 
> > Actually, in the scenario yo=
u describe, each of the individuals 
> would
> > now have a lower novelty, =
the original individual included. This
> > reflects that the area around th=
ese individuals in behavior space is
> > more dense than it previously was.=
 As more individuals come into a
> > particular area, the novelty of all of=
 them drops, and provides
> > pressure for individuals to do something new =
in order to be seen as 
> novel.
> > 
> > Let me know if you have any more =
implementation questions, I'll be
> > releasing my source based off the rtN=
EAT package in the next few 
> weeks.
> > 
> > Joel 
> > 
> > --- In neat@y=
ahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@>
> > wrote:
> > >
> >=
 > Hello,
> > > 
> > > I implemented novelty search and the maze navigation=
 task (it 
> > > works! :)), but I need to ask you about something. 
> > > =

> > > So when a new individual is spawned from the population, its 
> nove=
lty is 
> > > computed based on the domain-specific distance measure to all=
 
> other 
> > > behaviors in the population and the archive, right. 
> > >=
 
> > > But what about the population itself, should every individual 
> th=
ere 
> > > recompute its sparseness on every evaluation, based on the new 
=
> > > circumstances? 
> > > 
> > > I ask this because when I observe the sp=
arseness (I assume 
> sparseness 
> > > equals fitness) of the individuals,=
 say one happens to be in a 
> very 
> > > sparse area so it receives a hig=
h fitness score. But then a 
> couple of 
> > > other individuals come into=
 this area, so it becomes more dense. 
> But 
> > > that first individual s=
till has a high fitness score? Is this 
> right? 
> > > 
> > > Peter
> > >
=
> >
